texts.value: G-protein coupled receptor that functions as a receptor for endogenous enkephalins and for a subset of other opioids. Ligand binding causes a conformation change that triggers signaling via guanine nucleotide-binding proteins (G proteins) and modulates the activity of down-stream effectors, such as adenylate cyclase. Signaling leads to the inhibition of adenylate cyclase activity. Inhibits neurotransmitter release by reducing calcium ion currents and increasing potassium ion conductance. Plays a role in the perception of pain and in opiate-mediated analgesia. Plays a role in developing analgesic tolerance to morphine

May form homooligomers. Forms a heterodimer with OPRM1 (By similarity). Interacts with GPRASP1 (PubMed:12142540, PubMed:15086532). Interacts with RTP4; the interaction promotes cell surface localization of the OPRD1-OPRM1 heterodimer (By similarity)
Detected in oocytes (at protein level). Detected in brain cortex, hypothalamus, hippocampus and olfactory bulb. Detected in oocytes

Ubiquitinated. A basal ubiquitination seems not to be related to degradation. Ubiquitination is increased upon formation of OPRM1:OPRD1 oligomers leading to proteasomal degradation; the ubiquitination is diminished by RTP4
Belongs to the G-protein coupled receptor 1 family

features.description: improved maturation and increased expression at the cell surface; dbSNP:rs1042114
